unnormalised: The scent of monsoon hung heavy in the air over the Vidarbha fields. Farmer Ramrao, wiping sweat from his brow, surveyed his cotton crop. The lush green promised a good yield, a welcome change after the drought-stricken years. But the joy was tempered with worry – the dreaded bollworm had started its insidious work.

The lush green promised a good yield, a welcome change after the drought-stricken years. But the joy was tempered with worry – the dreaded bollworm had started its insidious work.

unnormalised: Ramrao remembered his grandfather’s methods, relying on neem oil and hand-picking pests. But the scale of the infestation this year was overwhelming. His neighbor, Kishanlal, was already on his third round of pesticide spraying. The allure of a quick fix, the promise of saving his hard-earned Rs., was strong. He consulted Dr. Patil at the local Krishi Vigyan Kendra.
normalised: Ramrao remembered his grandfather’s methods, relying on neem oil and hand-picking pests. But the scale of the infestation this year was overwhelming. His neighbor, Kishanlal, was already on his third round of pesticide spraying. The allure of a quick fix, the promise of saving his hard-earned rupees, was strong. He consulted Doctor Patil at the local Krishi Vigyan Kendra.

unnormalised: Dr. Patil, a man known for his practical advice, cautioned against indiscriminate use. "Ramrao," he said, "remember the stories of the Green Revolution. While it brought food security, the excessive pesticide use left a bitter legacy. The soil is tired, beneficial insects are gone, and the pests are becoming resistant." He explained the concept of Integrated Pest Management (IPM), a balanced approach that combined biological control, cultural practices, and judicious use of pesticides.

unnormalised: Ramrao learned about pheromone traps to monitor bollworm activity, Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) sprays as a safer alternative, and the importance of crop rotation. He even attended a workshop organized by the Kendra on creating his own organic pesticides from cow urine and local herbs – a technique his grandfather would have approved of.

unnormalised: He started implementing the IPM strategies, carefully monitoring his fields. It was more labour intensive than simply spraying a chemical cocktail, requiring daily walks through the fields, examining leaves, and setting traps. But he noticed the return of ladybugs, natural predators of the bollworm. He also realized he was spending less on expensive chemicals.

But he noticed the return of ladybugs, natural predators of the bollworm. He also realized he was spending less on expensive chemicals.

unnormalised: This season, Ramrao’s yield wasn’t as high as Kishanlal’s who had gone all-in on chemical pesticides, but it was a healthy harvest, produced with a lighter touch on the earth. He had preserved the health of his soil, protected the beneficial insects, and lessened the risk of pesticide resistance. Moreover, his cotton fetched a slightly higher price in the market, labelled as "residue-free." He knew he was walking a more sustainable path, a path that honored the land that sustained him and his family on their 2000 sq ft farm. The battle against pests was ongoing, but Ramrao felt armed with knowledge and a newfound respect for the delicate balance of nature. He even planned to share his experiences with other farmers in the village, hoping to change the narrative of pesticide usage, one farm at a time. He knew there was a long way to go, but this was a start, a move towards a "Swachh Bharat" of agriculture, free from the clutches of harmful chemicals.
